## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 268, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Theory (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 488]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 260, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 361, 530]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 170, 710, 188]]<|/det|> The charge on the nucleus of an atom is ...................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 202, 591, 220]]<|/det|> The charge on a proton is ...................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 233, 764, 250]]<|/det|> The charge on electrons orbiting the nucleus is ...................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 248, 920, 266]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 279, 146, 297]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 279, 625, 297]]<|/det|> A nucleus of radium-226 has the nuclide notation shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 304, 541, 344]]<|/det|> \[^{226}_{88}\mathrm {Ra}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 358, 180, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 358, 698, 377]]<|/det|> Determine the number of protons in a nucleus of radium-226. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 388, 920, 406]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 420, 180, 439]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 420, 710, 439]]<|/det|> Determine the number of neutrons in a nucleus of radium-226. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 450, 920, 468]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 481, 178, 500]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 539, 500]]<|/det|> Radium has another isotope, radium-223. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 513, 641, 530]]<|/det|> Write the nuclide notation for radium-223 in the space. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 920, 593]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 606, 144, 625]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 499, 625]]<|/det|> Radium-226 has a half-life of 1600 years. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 637, 494, 655]]<|/det|> A sample contains \(8.0 \text{mg}\) of radium-226. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 839, 686]]<|/det|> Calculate the time for the sample to decay until only \(1.0 \text{mg}\) of radium-226 remains. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 745, 920, 763]]<|/det|>
